Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: BIOL 103 has been the most rewarding course so far in the Biology sequence. Previously, I was not very confident in my ability to read scientific papers. But after taking BIOL 103, I now feel that I can understand almost any paper, even if it takes a lot of effort. BIOL 103 also granted me my first opportunity to write a research proposal. I put in A LOT of hours into my proposal, and it was one of the most creatively challenging STEM assignment I have ever had. I've learned so much from BIOL 103, and I feel that it has had a huge impact on my career decisions--I feel much more strongly about majoring in Bio than ever before.
I learned in greater depth essential concepts of genetics and development.
You truly learn a lot about genetics and genetic experiments in the class. It introduces a different way of thinking where you have to apply the concepts you learn in class to different problems.
I learned how to write a research proposal as well as the specifics of developmental biology.
I gained a lot of insight on the processes of development and genetics, as well as how to approach writing a scientific research paper.

As a continuation of the biology series, Biology 103 furthered my understanding of biological sciences (specifically in genetics and evolutionary biology) and bettered my skills of approaching problems with experimental methods. Through the homeworks, I also learned more about conducting literature searches and creating an research proposal.

Decent expansion on concepts from the earlier bio modules. I think the intent was to teach us the processes of experimental biology, but it was presented too formulaically for anything to transfer to a lab environment.

I learned a lot of information about developmental biology and genetics, but I also became better at reading scientific papers. I also became better at thinking through experiments and how to design them, as well as how to assess results and think through what they might suggest.

An in-depth knowledge about the biology behind genetics (much more detailed than basic Mendelian genetics) and about the developmental process (going from zygote, blastula, gastrula, etc.).  In other words, how genes are expressed and how individuals develop.  Also because of the research proposal (which is split up as five homework assignments throughout the course), I became familiar with the process of writing a scientific paper and how to go about researching for biological evidence, possible connections, etc.
I was able to work on my scientific writing and research skills
I learned about the development of species, including humans, over time, and how genetics and evolution impact this process.
Basic development and genetics, with a focus on molecular pathways
More balanced insight into current and former states of genetics, in relation to developmental processes
This class was my favorite in the bio sequence so far. It provided the perfect balance between giving us biological knowledge and teaching us about the scientific method and experimentation.
Honestly not a ton. I took MCDB 200 and learned all the material I learned in this class except in greater depth. It was still fun, though!
I learned the approaches to writing a scientific paper
I did learn more about the scientific process, evaluating data, and experimental design and thinking.
I learned about the basics of developmental bio and new technologies in genetics. I developed skills in identifying what type of experiments to use for different purposes.
I learned about developmental biology and genetics and also how a research proposal is written.
I learnt how to write a research proposal and how to continuously study for a course
This helped me learn how experimental strategy is applied to genetics and development concepts.

I learned so much about developmental processes and animal models used in early experiments on development. This is a course that will go into so much depth, you'll wonder if you'll ever really need this information in the future, but in my opinion, this was my favorite module of the intro biology courses so far! You also learn how to craft a research proposal in this course, and having already applied for fellowships, I really wish I had taken this course before hand because I learned so many useful tips and database resources to research more on my topic of interest.
Basic genetics reasoning, an overview of embryonic development, how to conduct experiments in genetics
I learned about genetics, mostly mutations
A groundwork of knowledge in developmental biology as well as genetics, with a big focus on how experiments in these fields can be carried out.
I learned a lot about genetics and development, especially about specific genes and how they relate to development in model organisms.
None
I learned about genetics and development. I also learned skills in proposing a hypothesis and formulating experimental procedures through the homeworks each week.

I think I have acquired a good toolset in understanding how scientists pinpoint mutations responsible for diseases, as well as how to create those mutations and design experiments. We also learned how scientific techniques used to understand genetics changed over time and the modern technological developments that have revolutionized the field. I believe I also gained a good conceptual understanding of development and how cells interact with one another during early stages of growth.
I improved upon my problem solving skills.
A decent build-upon from the BIOL101 and 102
I learned how to study effectively and I learned about developmental biology and genetics

I became more knowledgeable and comfortable with thinking critically about genetics and the processes associated with biological development across different species, as well as with reading scientific papers, writing research proposals, and designing experiments.
Significantly enhanced my knowledge of genetics.
Basic human development, genetics, analyzing various experimental results.
Great overview of genetics
I learned a lot of information in a very short amount of time. It was a very well taught class in genetics and the quizzes were designed so that you had to think critically and apply your knowledge.
I gained a lot of knowledge about development--a topic I had not been exposed to before in the past. I also learned about modern-day genetic approaches to science.
How to write a research proposal.

I gained an understanding of development that I had never had before. Never before did I truly understand where zygotic division, gastrulation, neurulation, and other similar processes fit into the developmental process. There is obviously much left to learn, but I'm happy to have had this great introduction to the principles of development.
I got very good at designing experiments and figuring out the best ways to assess problems.
I learned how to better design experiments to prove a specific point.
I developed the skills to further my studies in biology and be able to succeed in future courses. I developed the skills to write a research proposal and do scientific research.
I learned about the key concepts of developmental biology.

I gained a deeper knowledge of developmental biology and genetics; and I learned many of the ways in which you can conduct scientific biological experiments for testing genetics and developmental processes.
building a scientific research proposal; the basics of development and the involvement of genetics in development
learning how to create a research proposal was really useful and helpful. it made science feel like a creative field. i also found the course material really fascinating
I learned a lot about the mechanisms of genetics and the tools that geneticists use to study genes and developmental disorders. I also learned how to write a scientific research proposal.
I learned about genetics and how to read scientific paper

I learned about the mechanisms underlying embryonic development, as well as the techniques and principles of genetics that permit research on animal and plant development. A skill I gained was the ability to apply my knowledge of gof and lof mutations to design experiments that would determine a particular gene's function. I gained insight into the differences between model organisms and their overall utility in investigating the expression of genes essential for development.

It is a very thorough introduction to genetics. Also, the scientific research proposal project, which is part of the p-sets really allows you to become familiar/comfortable working with scientific literature.
I learned basic knowledge in genetics and development of various different species.
I learned more about genetics and development. I learned how to formulate a simple research proposal.
Overview of development from the role of genetics to processes such as gastrulation and organogenesis.
How to write a research proposal.
I learned a lot about developmental biology, genetics, and how to approach reading and discussing scientific papers.
The basics of genetics and the advancement of genetic technologies.
Basics of genetics and development

The course basically goes over genetics and different experiments and interventions that can be preformed by manipulating genetics. You also learn how to bring writing into biology because you have to write an experimental proposal.

I learned how to write a research proposal. I also learned about development and how genetics work. I learned about the process of cleavage, gastrulation, neurulation, and organogenesis. I also learned how genetic screens work.
I learned quite a bit about the concepts of genetics and developmental biology, as well as the basics and intricacies of reading and writing scientific papers and project proposals.

I learned about concepts of genetics and development, such as how our genes regulate important parts of our development and how there are similarities in the development in different organisms. We also focused on a few distinct features of development and how these features were examples of genetic influence.

I loved how the course allowed a lot of room for coming up with our own research proposals. I felt like I had a creative outlet!

This course was very challenging and involved a lot of work, but I don't think it has any outstanding weaknesses. It is a very well-designed course. I just have one thing to point out--I didn't like how the final grades were determined. I think "20% A / 20% A- / 20% B+ / 20% B / 20% B- and lower" was reasonable, but it would be better if the grading was a more absolute--rather than relative--process. It would reduce stress and a sense of competition among students.
The quizzes were pretty hard and stressful but the course was generally well designed.

The questions in this class, as in the rest of the biology sequence in my experience, are very poorly written and do not truly test the knowledge and insight that should be gained in this class. The class focuses on wanting to use the techniques we learn about experimentation and combine it with knowledge of genetics and development, but it is not often the case. The quizzes and finals usually contain a good amount of questions that require the memorization of the most minute detail in the slides. The questions are also often very vague, leaving them open to interpretation, but are graded based on one, correct interpretation which is impossible to discern during the test.
This strong was well taught and structured.
The lectures can be confusing and hard to keep up with. I personally took advantage of the peer tutors and enrichment which significantly helped my understanding of the topics.
Terrific professor, the homework sequence was also really cool since each one built on the last.

This course ties together many of the things we learned in BIOL 101 and 102, so that was a strength. A weakness is section and the scientific papers. Writing one was very informative, but reading them and tediously going over them in section was a waste of time compared to different methods of learning the same topics. Another strength is the organization of the course and the entire sequence.

I think the best part of this course was actually the homework assignment.  While the lectures and discussion section readings were engaging, the homework assignment really set this course apart from my previous Yale biology courses.  I really enjoyed the process of working on one project week by week to create a final product I was fully immersed in and proud of.

I think this was the best bio module yet; Vivian Irish was a solid lecturer and Sam Lin was a very organized course manager. The material was often engaging and the quizzes and homework were pretty fair. Not life-changing, but given that it's the intro bio sequence it could be a whole lot worse. That said, quizzes and homework pretend to assess how one would fare as a scientist, when they really involve memorization and presentation of information in a very specific manner that lines up much better with the way some people think than others.

I think the homework assignment of designing an experiment is definitely a good idea - it's very unique and thought-provoking, and I felt like it was a great way to introduce students to research ideas. However, I feel like there could have been more guidance - often, it felt like I had no idea how to proceed. Maybe providing more examples or offering optional info sessions on how to structure parts of the proposal (or going over it in section) could help.

I learned a lot and the weekly quizzes helped me stay on top of the course material but I thought the formatting of the quizzes and tests could be improved to better reflect the student's knowledge. The wording was often tricky and confusing and the quizzes were rushed.
I think providing more practice questions, especially in the homework (which is currently just a research proposal), would be really helpful for preparing for the final exam.
The class was super complicated from the beginning, and Prof Irish didnt make it easier to understand. Shes not the best at explaining concepts and dumbing down things

Strengths: great professor, great content, very organized
Perhaps more exam-style practice material would have come in handy, as the psets were not traditional ones.
I liked the emphasis around the three types of experiments (catch it, break it, move it).

The professor went through a lot of the material quite fast so it was hard to keep up. You would need to know some of the material beforehand in order to keep up. Maybe going through the lecture slides before class would help familiarize yourself with the material.

This course was strong in the depth of certain topics. However, I feel like I do not know much about development, but rather about the details of a few specific examples. I cannot describe how an embryo develops into an adult, and I know very little about the actual process of gastrulation. I thought that genetics was covered more thoroughly, however, sometimes important topics were glassed over and given the same attention as esoteric facts/examples. Also, when Prof Irish made it so that a graphic appeared on the slide after clicking, it would not be on the printed out notes, which was super annoying.

I feel as if there are almost too many resources in the bio sequence. I get muddled when I get information from all these different sources (lecture, section, piazza, readings, etc). Also, the lectures need to be improved so that they are more focused on fundamental topics rather than specific examples.

Strengths: The organization of the course was great. Whenever I had questions, I knew what resources were available for me. While the homework was frustrating (especially initially when there are so much possibilities), I believe that having to work out a research proposal throughout the course was a strength because it allowed me to integrate what I learned in class into a project. In addition, it gave me a glimpse of what writing a research proposal would be like. In addition, Professor Irish, Professor Lin, and my TA were helpful in answering questions.

Weakness: During times, some lectures felt rushed when we were pressed for time towards the end of the lecture.
Good content. I liked the homework. Not a fan of the weekly quizzes.

Strength is the organization and the professor. Irish is AMAZING and truly loves this material. Samantha Lin is incredible at organizing this course and I'm so grateful to have her as the coordinator for the BIOL modules. One weakness is that it does feel section is so unrelated at times because we go over research papers and it feels so rushed. I do appreciate that they are trying to model more of a journal club though!

The lectures themselves were not bad, but the quizzes were pretty weird and the final exam to me seemed horrendously written (full of ambiguous statements, grammatical errors, etc). I think this course can be better at evaluating students in a way that doesn't feel as cutthroat and stressful. The material was not that complicated on its own, so it often felt like we were being evaluated on our propensity to make silly mistakes. I also felt like it could've gone into a little bit more detail - I feel like I learned the least amount of information in this class out of the 101-103 sequence so far.

Professor Irish clearly knows a lot about bio but isn't the best lecturer. I think it would be better if she assumed none of us knew anything about bio and would just explain everything instead of skipping or glossing over important basics!
very good TAs and professor

Strengths: Irish is a pretty good lecturer, Lin is great
Weaknesses: The structure of this course is a mess and the assignments need to be reevaluated.
I think this was a good introductory course but sometimes the concepts could have been explained better.

Strengths: minimal work
Weaknesses: many. The course is poorly taught. A strong background in genetics is assumed to do well. The slides are mostly just pictures with no words and are not explained. Quiz questions were obscure, poorly worded, and oftentimes meant to trick you. No clear feedback was given for quiz answers.
I wish the sections were organized differently, I didn't get much out of section. Questions during lecture were always answered though, which was really nice.

I think it was beneficial that the sections were devoted to reading and interpreting scientific papers and the homework to writing a research proposal. These are good skills for anyone interested in science research.
The discussion sections are awesome w/r/t student involvement.
It can be very interesting, however the lectures aren't well presented and the content for very dry towards the end

Strengths-- organized, engaging 
Weaknesses-- lectures were sometimes unclear but that's fine since we could clarify on piazza and ask for help so it all worked out

The strengths include that the class is very straightforward and clear, with many opportunities to seek help if needed (Enrichment, Piazza, peer tutors, etc.). Also, I am a fan of the weekly quizzes in that they keep you on track throughout the semester and help you to digest the material gradually as opposed to in preparation for one stressful midterm.
Some of the lectures went too fast.
Theres a lot of material but the psets do not reinforce lecture content. The research project was interesting but time consuming.
piazza was great

This course could be improved by using sections to help students prepare for the quizzes better. I found it very difficult to predict the types of questions that would be asked on the quizzes and the responses that were expected.

The homeworks were a lot more time consuming than the professor made it out to be. Also, I just wasn't a fan of the strict grading on an such open ended assignment. I felt as though there wasn't much guidance for the homework especially when past assignments were not returned until after the next assignment was already due.

I thought that the concepts were very interesting, but had the feeling that too much information was crammed into the course, making it difficult to truly grasp any of the information.

In addition, I was not a fan of the homework assignments. I prefer problem sets, which allow me to practice the information learned that week. As someone who has conducted research before, I feel like the assignment supported an unrealistic approach to forming a research proposal. I did not learn anything from the work and it was not engaging.

Overall, I liked the course because I am extremely passionate about biology, but this has been my least favorite module so far.

The strength of the course is that it covered a lot of material in a short period of time. The weakness of this course was that the quizzes hardly reflected students effort in the class, and that you could spend hours studying the material only to be faced with a vague or trick question on the quiz and lose it all. Specific examples almost always confused the students more. The setup of the class was very stressful with the weekly quizzes, and the homework assignment was tedious and took hours and hours.

Strengths:
- Content is well-organized
- With respect to content, doesn't go too deep but also isn't too shallow
- Research proposal idea is cool and gives a good, practical view of what is learned in class

Weaknesses:
- Lack of normal homework assignments made it more difficult to process what was learned in lecture; problems from the book helped a bit, but not completely
- Would be nice to emphasize more that examples of processes given in class are just examples meant to show general principles
The lectures were well organized but not so much interesting or engaging.

This course was helpful in teaching students how to learn a concept from a research perspective. However, the analytical skills necessary to do well in the class were often overlooked in the broad spectrum of the course.

I thought the homeworks were both a strength and a weakness. It helped to be creative as a real scientist would, but some other homework problems that dealt with course material itself would have been helpful too.
This course was good in that it taught us not just what things are, but how to apply them. I believe, however, that the homework was unreasonably involved.

The strengths of this course are that it is set up in a way that encourages cooperation and this was seen through the studying that was seen between students. The study guides were very helpful. The weaknesses were that sometimes the questions weren't answered on Piazza. Also the grading was always fair between TAs since some graded easier.
The quizzes are incredibly hard, niche quizzes. I dont think they fairly evaluated my knowledge of the content, even though I did do well on them.
The weekly quizzes were stressful, and tested material in unexpected and sometimes borderline unfair ways. I felt like even if I studied the material for hours, I still wouldn't be able to do well.

I felt as though the sections were a definite weakness because we barely went through stuff related to the quizzes or final exam. It was just reading outside papers. They were some what relevant to some material we learned, but I felt as though sections could be better geared for the course to prep for the application type questions we received on quizzes and the final. 
I liked the help from the peer tutors, in explaining some concepts, because I was unable to attend enrichment hours.

I thought it the course was a little scattered and could have proceeded in more of a organized, progressive way where one module flowed into the other. Some modules formed a coherent hold, and some seemed disjointed.

i was troubled by the professor's language use of "marriage" when referring to reproduction. it showed up both on our quiz and in class. marriage has no place in a biology class as it is not a requisite for reproduction.
The lectures were interesting, and discussion sections were very helpful to learning, but grade feedback was sometimes an issue because we couldnt tell what we needed to fix for the next assignments.
The papers were a pain to read but once you understood them they made a lot of sense. Some topics weren't covered in full detail or we ran out if time and I was left confused

The strengths of this course are (a) its extension of concepts learned in BIOL 101 and 102 into the field of genetics and (b) Prof. Irish's strong background in genetics research and confidence in lecturing about the material covered in this course. One weakness of this course is that there is a severe lack of genetics at the beginning of the course (more emphasis on development), with the terms "lof mutation" and "gof mutation" thrown around without enough context regarding how scientists actually generate such mutations.

I think that although the information in the course was interesting, it was taught in a scattered manner without any emphasis on certain topics. Thus, I found it to be difficult to prepare for quizzes and exams. Also, although the psets were interesting, I found there to be no real instruction and did not have anything to do with class thus I didn't really gain much from it and it did not prepare me for quizzes and exams. I also found discussion section to not be very helpful as we would just go over a paper, for I think I would have preferred it to be more lecture based where we could ask specific questions about the lecture or it be geared towards preparing us for what we needed to know. 

Overall though, the material was quite interesting.
The course was interesting and covered a variety of material, but some of the lectures were oversimplified.

strengths: organization of course topics with additional information on study guides
weaknesses: can't think of any
Clearer grading on the research proposal and less ambiguous questions on the quizzes and final exam.
I like how organized it is but dislike the fact that so much of our grade depends on the quizzes, which a lot of good test takers score well on and curve the class up.

The test and quizzes in this class often pose questions that are worded in ways that prompt the student to "out smart" the teacher instead of demonstrating what they have learned. Tricky questions with no clear logistical reasoning behind them and whose correct answers don't clearly pertain to something in the class or demonstrate learning  shouldn't be how they teach.

Strengths: interesting material and engaging discussions
Weakness: Slides were not always thoroughly explained, needed to ask Prof. and peer tutors questions to fully understand concepts
Strengths are that it is very interesting and engaging. Weakness is that that there are so few quizzes that each quiz carries a lot of weight.
The course is a lot like the other bio sequences. The quizzes are pretty difficult and I think a lot of the questions have room for interpretation which makes answering and grading difficult.

The strengths was that it was very structured. I liked how they walked us through the process of writing a research proposal. However, I felt like the lectures were not very good at informing us about the materials. Also, I felt like they could have done a better job at explaining some aspects of the research proposal.

Strengths: Instructor, TA's, and general participation in section
Weakness: The general size of the class, but that really isn't avoidable

Strengths are the course material; genetics and development, to me, was very interesting to learn about. Another strength is that discussion sections focused on reviewing material for the most part, rather than reading papers. Weaknesses are that the course tends to be a bit disjointed, in that the material we learn one day can be completely different than what we learn the following lecture. Another weakness is the amount of stress caused by the weekly quizzes, and the sometimes ambiguous wording on the questions that led to students losing points.
Take it if you have to take it, it isn't bad, but not the most interesting class either.

Yes! If you are considering majoring in Biology, you will gain so much insight from this course. It will give you a good sense of what direction of Biology you might want to pursue, and will teach you how to read scientific papers and write a research proposal. It is difficult and a lot work, but it is very rewarding!
Even if you are not majoring in Biology, if you have taken BIOL 101 and 102, you might want to take BIOL 103. It was cool to see how concepts learned in BIOL 101 and 102 came together in this course.
No, the BIOL sequence is run and is tested very poorly
Yes, if you are interesting in majoring in STEM and are interested in genetics and development, this course is a good introduction.

I would recommend this course to a student interested in biology. The homework is also structured differently than the other modules. It does feel like a lot of work especially with the weekly quizzes.

This is the best one in the bio sequence. What you put into the homework assignments you will get out, and while it is difficult and I certainly had no clue how to start at first, it ended up being a great experience.
I'd only recommend this course if you have to take it. Even though the topics are interesting, the work and overall gain of the course isn't worth it if you're not fulfilling a requirement.
Yes, because this course has been my favorite part of the biology sequence so far.

Don't take it if you don't have to, but obviously you have to take it if you're reading this. It's a fine course -- it's still intro bio, and it's stressful and annoying for that reason, but 103 was actually somewhat more enjoyable than I expected.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in biology. It's difficult and intensive, but the information is interesting and doubtless important if students want to go farther in biology.

If you are a biology major or pre-med, you have to take it either way.  But be forewarned, the weekly homework assignments are death (start them early because you might run into some problems, ie. your disease and gene of interest do not match), the quizzes are much more about applying basic knowledge and not about the examples themselves, and that this is not like the other biology sequence courses.  This was my least favorite course of the bio sequence.  I personally struggled with it quite a lot and it made me reconsider changing my major: I am no longer an MCDB major.  But as long as you actually put in time and effort to learn the material and do the homework ahead of time, you will be fine.
I thought the material was interesting and if you put the work in and stay on top of the material you will be fine.
I would recommend this class to students who are STEM majors or pre-med and have this course as a pre-requisite.
Lol premed

Yes, its taught well by Prof. Irish, interesting and applicable concepts. 
Of course, likely, youll be taking it because you have to
Great class! professor Irish and professor Lin are both great caring instructors!
This class is super required if you're a STEM major. From what I've heard from people who take 103 in the spring, TAKE IT IN THE FALL. Vivian Irish is wonderful and her lectures are straight forward.
Take it if you need it

This course was not bad. The quizzes were fair, but the final was hard and the research proposal took ~8 hours per week up to week 4. I learned a lot, but sometimes complex topics and important background were briefly stated and left behind, causing student confusion. However, I got the feeling that the professors and TF's really wanted the students to succeed. My experience was a net positive.
It's not a bad course, but only take it if you have to.
Yes, I would recommend this class. For many people, it is a required class, but nevertheless, it provided a good overview of genetics and developmental biology.
Yes
Not a fan of the 101/103 style weekly quizzes, but a good course otherwise. Interesting material, and I enjoyed the homeworks.

YES I LOVED THIS COURSE! I had an amazing TA and Professor, so that was largely way. I can't speak for the on-cycle Biology modules, but this course taught in the fall was absolutely wonderful. I really look at development in a different lens now and I appreciate the genetics that underly what makes us how we are today. It's an incredible thing to learn, though of course there is still SO much more to development and this course is just a dabble into this area of biology, but it is still so meaningful nonetheless!

Meh, maybe. It was my least favorite of the intro modules so far, but that's probably just based on personal taste for the subject material. It's not particularly difficult, you just have to stay on top of things for the quizzes and be aware that the grading is very competitive.
better than 101 and 102
Yes because you have to take for a lot of majors, just be ready to ask a lot of questions!
Nobody takes 103 for fun so I don't even know why they ask if I would recommend its not like we get a choice.
I would only if they need it.
Yes, the course was very interesting and very important for anyone looking to pursue biology or research in their career.
Yes, it's a good class.
Only if they have to take it, which you probably do if you have to take it
Yes-- if it's required for your major or if you're premed
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in biology!
I would not recommend the course to anyone who does not need it.
Yes, if you wish to pursue any higher-level biology course.

I think the course offers a great introduction to the topic of development. I think it was lacking in its instruction of genetics, which is a shame because I love genetics, but overall it is a good way to gauge interest of these topics. The homework assignments, however, were not productive yet very time-consuming.
Only as a requirement.
This course gives a great introduction to genetics and especially development, and it would be great for anyone who seeks to continue studying biology, regardless of their field.
If you are doing the Bio sequence, you might as well continue but if not, don't take this class.
I would only recommend this course to a student who needs it as a major requirement, as it was not as enjoyable as it could have been given the interesting subject matter.
Yes I would. It was quite interesting and anybody interested in biology should stick it out through this sequence.
I would recommend this course to another student because it actually teaches you a lot and helps you to understand how pertinent things in our lives work.
This has definitely been my favorite biology module so would recommend this course to others. The professor was very passionate and very helpful.
If you need it for your major. Otherwise, no way.
Yes, if they are interested in pursuing the topic.
I am not sure; it is good for students building a foundation in Biology but the course could be improved in how its organized and in how the modules build on each other and flow.
yes i don;t know why everyone hates on this class so much. it was really interesting.
Bio 103 was definitely more interesting than 101 and 102, but parts were overwhelming. Be prepared to do more scientific writing than youve probably ever done, but overall its a good course.
Take it if you need it for your major

If you are a bio major, you don't have a choice. Nevertheless, BIOL 103 was the most rewarding of the three modules thus far, as you are challenged to synthesize and extend many different developmental/genetics concepts within a short period of time. It is easy to misinterpret experimental questions on quizzes, so be careful to read the questions thoroughly.
I would recommend it  for those who must take it as a prereq.
This is a fine intro course, but if someone is very interested in biology, they'll want to take a more advanced class.
I would recommend if they need a challenging Sc credit.

I would tell another student that the subject material is one of the most intersting of any course I have taken at Yale, however the structure of testing and homework is badly set up.  It did not seem to serve its purpose of testing knowledge of the material.
If you need to take the intro bio sequence, it's a solid intro course.
Yes; must take for premed or Biology major!
Yes because you learn about various aspects in genetics that can be used in later research.
The material is super interesting but its difficult so you should only really take the course if you have to for your major.
I would recommend this course because you gain a better and deeper understanding of biology. You also get to develop your critical thinking skills as well as your writing skills.
Yes, It's a good course with important material and taught very well

I would recommend this course if a student has a strong interest in genetics and development, and is willing to put in the effort that this course required. @Pre-meds: you are required to take this, so just put in the work, and you will definitely get through it!
